importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication marks the latest update on the resumption of flights between China and India, signaling a recent diplomatic and economic shift.
Direct flights between India and China were suspended during the pandemic, and the resumption in 2025 marks a significant five-year gap in bilateral air connectivity.

The US raised tariffs on Indian imports to 50% in September 2025, which contributed to geopolitical tensions and indirectly influenced India-China relations by pushing both nations toward economic cooperation.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from 2020 to 2025 represents the five-year freeze in direct flights between India and China, interrupted only by a diplomatic thaw following high-level engagement and shifting global trade dynamics.
The current timeline reflects the post-pandemic diplomatic revival, initiated by Prime Minister Modi’s visit to China and the broader geopolitical realignment under US trade pressures.

keyTakeAways: China Eastern Airlines will resume Shanghai-Delhi flights from November 9, 2025, after a five-year freeze.
The resumption of direct flights is part of a broader diplomatic thaw between China and India, driven by mutual interest in countering US trade policies.
Flights will operate three times a week on Wednesdays, Saturdays, and Sundays.
The move follows Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s first visit to China in over seven years, during which both countries discussed trade and border security.

The revival of flights occurs amid heightened US trade tensions, including 50% tariffs on Indian goods and proposed 100% tariffs on China and India, which may have incentivized economic cooperation between India and China.
India’s largest carrier, IndiGo, previously announced daily nonstop flights between Kolkata and Guangzhou, indicating a broader trend of increased bilateral air connectivity.
Direct flights were suspended during the pandemic and after deadly border clashes in 2020, when four Chinese and 20 Indian soldiers were killed in the worst violence in decades.
The resumption of flights reflects a strategic realignment in Indo-China relations as both countries seek economic resilience in the face of US trade pressure.

summaryOfNewsArticle: China Eastern Airlines has announced the resumption of direct flights between Shanghai and Delhi starting November 9, 2025, after a five-year hiatus. This move follows a diplomatic thaw between China and India, initiated by Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s visit to China and driven by mutual economic interests amid aggressive US trade policies, including a 50% tariff on Indian goods and proposed 100% tariffs on China and India. The flights will operate three times weekly, on Wednesdays, Saturdays, and Sundays. The suspension of flights prior to 2025 was due to both the pandemic and deadly border clashes in 2020, which killed 24 soldiers. The revival of air links reflects a strategic shift toward economic cooperation between the two nations as a response to external trade pressures.
title: China Eastern Airlines to resume flights to India after five-year freeze
